data.test_name: Centre of Mass and Law of Conservation of Momentum (Hard)

1.q_string:
Two small particles of equal masses start moving in opposite directions from a point A in a horizontal circular orbit. Their tangential velocities are v and 2v, respectively, as shown in the figure. Between collisions, the particles move with constant speeds.

                                

After making how many elastic collisions, other than that at A, will these two particles again reach the point A?

A body of mass 4m is lying in x-y plane at rest. It suddenly explodes into three pieces. Two pieces, each of mass m, move perpendicular to each other with equal speeds (v). The total kinetic energy generated due to explosion is

A shell is fired from a cannon with a velocity v ms–1 at an angle θwith the horizontal direction. At the highest point in its path, it explodes into two pieces of equal masses. One of the pieces retraces its path to the cannon. The speed of the other pieces immediately after the explosion is

A sphere A of mass 1 kg moving along x-axis with a velocity of 2.0 ms<sup>–1</sup> collides with another sphere B of 0.5 kg initially at rest. After collision, sphere A moves with a velocity of 1.0 ms<sup>–1</sup> in a direction making an angle of 60<sup>o</sup> with x-axis. What is the velocity of sphere B?

A sphere of mass 1 kg is connected to a spring of spring constant 5.0 N and a force is applied on the sphere along the x-axis. What is the velocity of the sphere when it is displaced through a distance of 10 cm along the x-axis?

q_option: Statement – I is true, Statement – II is true, Statement – II is not a correct explanation of Statement – I.
Statement – I is true, Statement – II is false.
Statement – I is false, Statement – II is true.
Statement – I is false, Statement – II is true, Statement – II is the correct explanation of Statement – I.
1.q_string:
Direction: This question has a statement I and Statement II. Of the four choices given after the Statements, choose the one that best describes the two Statements.

Statement – I: A point particle of mass m moving with speed v collides with a stationary point particle of mass M. If the maximum energy loss possible is given as \(f\left(\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}\right),\) then \(f=\left(\frac{m}{M+m}\right)\)

Statement – II: Maximum energy loss occurs when the particles get stuck together as a result of the collision.

A uniform force of \((3 \mathrm{i}+\mathrm{j}) \mathrm{N}\) acts on a particle of mass \(2 \mathrm{kg}\). Hence, the particle is displaced from position (2i +\(k\) ) metre to position \((4 i+3 j-k)\) metre. The work done by the force on the particle is

A mass m moves with a velocity v and collides inelastically with another identical mass at rest. After the collision, the first mass moves with velocity v/3 in a direction perpendicular to the initial direction of motion. Find the speed of the second mass after the collision.

A metal ball of mass 2 kg moving with a speed of 36 km/h has a head-on collision with a stationary ball of mass 3 kg. If, after the collision, the two balls move together, then the loss in KE due to collision is

A spring scale is adjusted to read zero. Particles of mass 1 g fall on the pan of the scale and collide elastically and they rebound upward with the same speed. If the height of fall of particles is 2 metres and their rate of collision is 100 particles per second, then the scale reading (in grams) will be
In a head-on elastic collision of a very heavy body moving at V with a light body at rest, the velocity of the heavy body after collision is
A particle of mass m and velocity V→collides elastically with a stationary particle of mass m. Calculate the angle between the velocity vectors of the two particles after the collision.

q_option: v1 = 3 ms–1; v2 = 3 ms–1
v1 = 23 ms–1; v2 = 3 ms–1
v1 = 33 ms–1; v2 = 33 ms–1
v1 = 43 ms–1; v2 = 43 ms–1
1.q_string: A ball moving with a speed of 9 ms<sup>–1</sup> strikes an identical stationary ball such that after the collision, the direction of each ball makes an angle of 30<sup>o</sup> with the original line of motion (figure). Find the speeds of the two balls after the collision.

A steel ball of radius 2 cm is initially at rest. It is struck head-on by another steel ball of radius 4 cm travelling with a velocity of 81 cm/s. If the collision is elastic their respective final velocities are

A bob of mass M is suspended by a massless string of length L. The horizontal velocity v at position A is just sufficient to make it reach the point B. The angle at which the speed of the bob is half of that at A satisfies is
